606.24
   Personating an officer - see GEN. OFF.
642.20
   Inspection of commercial vehicles which haul waste material  - see S.U. &
P.S.
1060.01
248.01  COMPOSITION.
   The regular police force of the City shall consist of a Police Chief, a
Police Captain, five Police Sergeants, fourteen Police Patrolmen, a Dispatcher
Supervisor, five Dispatchers, an Administrative Secretary, and other personnel
as Council shall from time to time determine.  All police employees shall be
appointed by the Mayor, with the concurrence of City Council. 
(Ord. 94-20.  Passed 2-24-94; Ord. 2001-40.  Passed 10-11-01; Ord. 2002-20. 
Passed 4-25-02; Ord. 2005-27.  Passed 4-28-05.)
248.02  AUXILIARY POLICE UNIT.
   (a)   An Auxiliary Police Unit is hereby established to operate within and
as a part of the Police Department. The Unit shall consist of a complement of
auxiliary policemen in such number as Council shall, from time to time,
determine, all of whom shall be residents of the City and all of whom shall
serve without compensation and shall not be eligible for membership in the
Police Relief and Pension Fund.
(Adopting Ordinance)
   (b)   The Mayor shall be the executive head of the Unit and shall make all
appointments and removals of auxiliary police officers, subject to the advice
and consent of Council, and he shall prescribe reasonable rules and regulations
for the organization, training, administration, control and conduct of the
Unit. The Chief of Police shall have exclusive control of the stationing and
transferring of all auxiliary police officers, under such general rules and
regulations as the Mayor prescribes from time to time.
   (c)   From time to time Council shall make and designate appropriations for
the purpose of providing uniforms, equipment and related needs for the use of
the auxiliary police officers and for the operation of the Unit, all such
materials to continue and remain the property of the City. Each auxiliary
policeman to whom the same are issued shall be responsible for the proper care
and maintenance thereof and the return thereof to the City upon demand or
instructions by the Mayor or the Chief of Police, in as reasonably good
condition as when originally issued. Nothing herein contained shall be
construed to intend or involve the payment of any compensation to such
auxiliary police officers or otherwise to make them employees of the City,
except as necessarily inferred from the provisions hereof.
248.03  POLICE MATRON. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section
248.03 was repealed by Ordinance 80-69, passed March 12, 1981.)
248.04  SCHOOL CROSSING GUARD.
   (a)   The position of school crossing guard is hereby created.
   (b)   The school crossing guard shall be appointed by the Mayor, with the
advice and consent of Council, and shall perform such duties and work such
hours as are assigned by the Chief of Police.
(Ord. 69-2. Passed 1-9-69.)
248.05  SUBSTITUTE POLICE MATRON.(REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section
248.05 was repealed by Ordinance 2002-21, passed April 11, 2002.)
248.06  EMERGENCY SERVICE TO OTHER MUNICIPALITIES AND TOWNSHIPS (MUTUAL AID).
   (a)   Upon request of a neighboring jurisdiction, whether or not contiguous
to this municipal corporation, the Northwood Police Department may furnish
police manpower and equipment to aid the requesting jurisdiction in an
emergency, to the extent such manpower and equipment is available.
   (b)   Any request for assistance shall be made by the highest ranking
officer of the requesting party on duty at the time.  The decision as to
whether, and the extent to which, manpower and equipment is available for
assistance shall be made by the Chief of Police or by the Shift Supervisor on
duty at the time of the request.
   (c)   Even though a request for assistance has not been made, a Northwood
police officer who sees a police officer of another jurisdiction in distress or
receives an urgent call for aid to any such officer in distress nearby, may, in
the exercise of sound discretion and reasonable judgment, go into the other
jurisdiction to render assistance to the officer in distress.
   (d)   Personnel of the Northwood Police Department acting under this section
outside of the municipal corporation may participate in any pension or
indemnity fund established by the municipal corporation of the same extent as
if they were acting within the municipal corporation, and are entitled to all
rights and benefits under R.C. 4123.01 to 4123.94 the same as if they were
performing police services within the municipal corporation.
   (e)   In responding to a call for assistance under this section, Northwood
police personnel shall be considered to be acting within the scope of their
employment while enroute to or from, and while acting within, the requesting
jurisdiction, and while acting within any other jurisdiction if engaged in
fresh pursuit.  To the extent Ohio R.C. 701.02 and Chapter 2744 are applicable
to the operation of police departments, it is applicable to Northwood police
personnel rendering service outside the municipal corporation pursuant to this
section.
(Res. 81-12. Passed 10-8-81; Ord. 2007-32.  Passed 9-27-07.)
248.07  REWARDS.
   (a)   The Chief of Police is hereby authorized, on a case by case basis, to
offer rewards for information leading to the arrest and conviction of persons
damaging and/or maliciously destroying City owned property located in the City.
   (b)   The maximum reward shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) for any
misdemeanor and five hundred dollars ($500.00) for any felony for which
information is furnished to the Police Department, enabling the Department to
identify, arrest and obtain a conviction for vandalism or malicious destruction
of City property.
   (c)   The Chief of Police shall advertise a reward on any case that warrants
a reward and no reward shall be paid for any offense unless and until the Chief
has advertised for the same.
(Ord. 83-53. Passed 8-25-83.)
248.08  LAW ENFORCEMENT TRUST FUND.
   (a)   The Finance and Revenue Director is hereby authorized and directed to
accept cash, vehicles and other property in accordance with Ohio R.C. 2933.43,
the Contraband Seizure Forfeiture Act.  However, any acceptance of real estate
by the Director shall be subject to approval by ordinance of Council.
   (b)   The Director is hereby directed to place all cash received into a
special trust fund, entitled Special Law Enforcement Trust Fund No. 236, to be
used solely for law enforcement purposes. Such Fund shall be separate and apart
from all other special funds.
(Ord. 87-15. Passed 6-11-87.)
248.09  LAW ENFORCEMENT MANDATORY DRUG FINE FUND.
   (a)   The Finance and Revenue Director is hereby authorized and directed to
accept cash from the mandatory drug fines imposed on convicted drug offenders
in accordance with Ohio R.C. 2925.03(J) and (K).
   (b)   The Director is hereby directed to place all cash received into
Special Law Enforcement Mandatory Drug Fine Fund No. 235, to be used solely for
the Police Department's law enforcement efforts pertaining to drug offenses.
Such Fund shall be separate and apart from all other special funds.
(Ord. 87-16. Passed 6-11-87.)
248.10  ELIGIBILITY TO TAKE CIVIL SERVICE TESTS.  (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section
248.10 was repealed by Ordinance 2006-20, passed June 8, 2006.)
248.11  ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER.
   (a)   The position of Animal Control Officer is hereby created.
   (b)   The Animal Control Officer shall be appointed by the Mayor with the
concurrence of City Council and shall perform such duties and work such hours
as are assigned by the Chief of Police.
(Ord. 2002-23.  Passed 4-11-02.)
248.12  TRAFFIC CAMERA OPERATOR.
   (a)   The position of Traffic Camera Operator is hereby created.
   (b)   Traffic Camera Operators shall be appointed by the Mayor with the
concurrence of City Council and shall perform such duties and work such hours
as are assigned by the Chief of Police.
(Ord. 2005-28.  Passed 4-28-05.)
CHAPTER 250
Volunteer Fire Department
EDITOR'S NOTE: Ordinance 82-36, passed June 10, 1982, adopted the Constitution
of the Northwood Fire Department. Copies of such Ordinance and Constitution are
available, at cost, from the Clerk of Council.
This chapter, previously a codification of Ordinances 63-1, passed January 3,
1963, and 80-15, passed June 12, 1980, was re-enacted in its entirety by
Ordinance 84-18, passed March 22, 1984.
250.01   Authority of Administrator.
250.02   Fire Chief, Deputy Chief and District Chiefs; records.
250.03   Assistant Chiefs. (Repealed)
250.04   Membership requirements.
250.05   Practice drills.
250.06   Attendance at drills; loss of membership.
250.07   Compensation.
250.08   Appointment of Fire Chief.
250.09   Appointment and removal of subordinate officers; removal of Chief.
250.10   Rules and regulations.
250.11   Rates for ambulance or EMS transportation.
250.12   Rates for use of emergency equipment; hazardous materials incidents.
250.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Volunteer Firemen's Dependents Fund - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 146
   Fire protection contracts - see Ohio R.C. 307.05, 505.44, 717.02
   Fire departments in cities - see Ohio R.C. 737.08 et seq.
250.01  AUTHORITY OF ADMINISTRATOR.
   The Administrator, under the authority of Section
8.01 of the City Charter, shall be the executive head of the Volunteer Fire
Department. He or she shall be responsible for the prevention of fires, the
protection of life and property against fire and the provision of emergency
medical treatment and transportation for the City.
(Ord. 84-18. Passed 3-22-84.)
250.02  FIRE CHIEF, DEPUTY CHIEF AND DISTRICT CHIEFS; RECORDS.
   (a)   Until such time as the City establishes a paid full-time Fire
Department, there shall be one Fire Chief, one Deputy Chief and two District
Fire Chiefs in the Volunteer Fire Department with one District Chief having
jurisdiction over Fire Station No. 1 and the other District Chief having
jurisdiction over Fire Station No. 2. In the absence or disability of the Fire
Chief, the Deputy Chief shall assume the responsibility of the Fire Chief under
the guidance of the Administrator.
   (b)   The Fire Chief shall keep, in convenient form, a complete record of
all fires. Such record shall include the time of the alarm, the location of the
fire, the cause of the fire (if known), the type of building, the name of the
owner and tenant, the purpose for which it was occupied, the value of the
building and its contents, the names of the members of the Department
responding to the alarm and such other information as he or she deems advisable
or as may be required from time to time by Council.
(Ord. 84-18.  Passed 3-22-84; Ord. 2007-33.  Passed 10-25-07.)
250.03  ASSISTANT CHIEFS. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section
250.03 was repealed by Ordinance 2007-33, passed October 25, 2007.)
250.04.  MEMBERSHIP REQUIREMENTS.
   All fire-fighters shall be at least eighteen years of age and able bodied.
All fire-fighters shall be able to perform the physical requirements necessary
to carry out fire-fighting duties and shall pass a satisfactory mental and
physical examination. They shall become members of the Volunteer Fire
Department only after a twelve-month probationary period and certification by
the State as required by Ohio R.C. 3303.07.
(Ord. 84-18. Passed 3-22-84.)
250.05  PRACTICE DRILLS.
   The Fire Chiefs or their authorized representatives shall hold practice
drills and give the fire-fighters instructions in approved methods of fire
fighting and fire prevention as required by State law.
(Ord. 84-18. Passed 3-22-84.)
250.06  ATTENDANCE AT DRILLS; LOSS OF MEMBERSHIP.
   All regular and probationary fire-fighters shall attend at least twenty-five
percent of the total number of drills, shall attend at least two drill days per
month, but shall not miss three consecutive drill days. Failure to comply with
the foregoing may result in the forfeiture of membership. Regular members and
recruits will be allowed excuses for funeral leave, illness (of the member),
work and/or vacation, to a total of three excuses per year, with not more than
one excuse being accepted per month and with the year commencing on the date of
the first leave. Requests for such absences shall be submitted in writing to
the District Chief. All excuses and discipline shall be handled by the District
Chief.
(Ord. 84-18. Passed 3-22-84.)
250.07  COMPENSATION.
   (a)   The compensation of a member of the Volunteer Fire Department shall be
based on a point system as follows, one point shall be equivalent to one hour
of the current rate of pay per the payroll ordinance.
(Ord. 96-8.  Passed 4-25-96; Ord. 2002-8.  Passed 3-14-02.)
   (b)   Those responding to emergency calls shall receive one point for the
first two hours of active duty per call, and, in addition, one point for every
one hour or fraction thereof after the first two hours of each call.
   (c)   Those attending scheduled training sessions and department related
duties shall receive one point for each hour or fraction thereof for such
training.
(Ord. 90-33.  Passed  8-23-90; Ord. 2002-8.  Passed 3-14-02.)
   (d)   The compensation for fire-fighter members shall be paid twelve times
annually, on a monthly basis.  Payrolls will be paid during the subsequent
month from which earned.
   Monthly payrolls shall be submitted by the Fire Chief to the Finance and
Revenue Department no later than the tenth day of the following month in which
compensation was earned.  Upon receipt of payroll time information from the
Fire Chief, the Finance and Revenue Department will process payroll with a
paycheck date of between the eleventh day and the twenty-fifth day of each
month.
   The effective date of this subsection shall be for any and all earned
compensation occurring on or after April 1, 1997.
(Ord. 97-13.  Passed 2-27-97; Ord. 2002-8.  Passed 3-14-02.)
250.08  APPOINTMENT OF FIRE CHIEF.
   Under the provisions of Section 4.05(C) of the City Charter, the Fire Chief
shall be appointed by the Mayor with the concurrence of a majority of the
members of Council.  (Ord. 84-18.  Passed 3-22-84.)
250.09  APPOINTMENT AND REMOVAL OF SUBORDINATE OFFICERS; REMOVAL OF CHIEF.
   Under the authority of Section
5.05 of the City Charter, the Administrator shall have the power and duty to
appoint, suspend or remove all subordinate officers and employees of the
Volunteer Fire Department, except the Fire Chief, who is subject to removal
only by the Mayor with the concurrence of a majority of the members of Council
under Section
4.05(C) of the Charter. 
(Ord. 84-18.  Passed 3-22-84.)
250.10  RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Administrator, with the assistance of the Fire Chief and the District
Chiefs, shall adopt and publish rules and regulations for the Volunteer Fire
Department pertaining to the following:
   (a)   The role of the Fire Chief, the District Chiefs, the Assistant Chiefs,
the officers and the fire-fighters;
   (b)   Job specifications and classifications for officers and fire-fighters,
including new recruits;
   (c)   The organizational conduct for any desired social arm and any
auxiliary, and the relationships of such group with the Department and the
facilities of the Department;
   (d)   Personnel practices and instructions, directions and orders within the
Department and other internal procedures for the operation of the fire
stations;
   (e)   The method of removal of any fire-fighter for cause, as pertaining to
these rules and regulations and any operating rules;
   (f)   Conduct of members in the fire stations and while representing the
Department and the role and responsibilities of the ranking officers in
controlling such conduct;
   (g)   Separation of the activities within the fire stations dealing with
fire/rescue training, instructions and conduct from organizational activities
that may be social in nature, as to time, place and event; and
   (h)   A grievance procedure and its system and process, including specific
steps, methods and definitions, so that a grievance beginning at any point
within the Fire Department, if not resolved, may have a remedy at a higher
level, extending to the Administrator.
(Ord. 84-18.  Passed 3-22-84.)
250.11  RATES FOR AMBULANCE OR EMS TRANSPORTATION.
   (a)   Rates for ambulance or emergency medical service transportation
performed by the City shall be as set forth in
Chapter 208 of this Administration Code - the General Fee Schedule. 
(Ord. 91-8.  Passed 3-28-91.)
   (b)   Such rates shall be charged in accordance with the fee schedule
established in Section
208.01.  The City, as its discretion, may waive or write off all or part of the
ambulance or emergency medical service transportation charges.
(Ord. 97-27.  Passed 4-24-97.)
   (c)   No person shall fail to pay charges for ambulance or emergency medical
service runs as set forth in
Chapter 208.
(Ord. 91-8.  Passed 3-28-91.)
250.12  RATES FOR USE OF EMERGENCY EQUIPMENT; HAZARDOUS MATERIALS INCIDENTS.
   (a)   Rates for the use of emergency equipment by the City shall be as set
forth in
Chapter 208 of this Administration Code - the General Fee Schedule.
   (b)   In addition to the fees provided for in subsection (a) hereof, the
City shall compensate any Fire Department personnel for time spent in
responding to and resolving any emergency involving hazardous materials at the
current City rate of pay for volunteer firefighters.  Any costs paid or
incurred by the City under this section shall also be deemed an additional
expense to be recovered from the responsible party.
   (c)   In the event that any equipment is destroyed by hazardous waste
through contamination, or otherwise, said equipment shall be replaced at the
currently existing cost of replacement at the time of loss.
(Ord. 99-56.  Passed 1-13-00.)
250.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates Section
250.11(d) shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, or the matter shall be
referred to the City Attorney for civil collection.
(Ord. 91-8.  Passed 3-28-91.)
CHAPTER 252
Investment of Surplus Funds
252.01   Policy.
252.02   Schedules and estimates.
252.03   Authorized investments. 
252.04   Limitations.
252.05   Treasury Investment Account.
252.06   Disposition of earnings.
252.07   Reports.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Deposit of public moneys - see Ohio R.C. 117.17
   Treasury Investment Fund - see Ohio R.C. 731.56 et seq.
   Disposition of fines and fees collected by Mayor - see Ohio R.C. 733.40
   Reimbursement of note and bond proceeds of temporary advances - see ADM.
236.04
252.01  POLICY.
   The City shall provide for the investment and the rendering productive of
any surplus moneys in any account or fund of the City which, from time to time,
will not be required to be used by the City for a period of six months or more.
Such funds shall be invested and managed as hereinafter provided.
(Ord. 65-3. Passed 1-28-65.)
252.02  SCHEDULES AND ESTIMATES.
   (a)   From time to time, the Finance and Revenue Director shall submit to
the Mayor and to the City Attorney a statement respecting moneys in the
Municipal Treasury or in the process of collection and a schedule showing the
probable requirements of money for the use of the City for a period of not less
than six months, together with a summarization and estimate as to whether such
surplus funds or any part thereof should be invested on behalf of the City. 
Acting jointly and unanimously, the Mayor, the City Attorney and the Finance
and Revenue Director may from time to time order investment of all or part of
such surplus funds as they deem advisable and in accordance with the provisions
hereof.
   (b)   The Finance Committee of Council shall serve in an advisory capacity
to such officials and shall be kept fully informed as to all actions taken
under the provisions hereof.
252.03  AUTHORIZED INVESTMENTS.
   Surplus Municipal funds may be invested as follows:
   (a)   In one or more savings accounts in any licensed bank in the State,
provided such funds are insured and/or secured adequately, as determined by the
Finance and Revenue Director;
   (b)   In notes and/or bonds of the City;
   (c)   In bonds, certificates or other obligations of the United States
government or those for the payment of principal and interest of which the
faith of the United States government is pledged;
   (d)   Discount notes of the Federal National Mortgage Association;
   (e)   Bonds issued by the Home Owners' Loan Corporation;
   (f)   Bonds of the State;
   (g)   Bonds of any municipal corporation in the State or other political
subdivision of the State.
252.04  LIMITATIONS.
   No investment provided in Section
252.03(b) through (g) shall be made at a price in excess of the current market
value of such bonds or other interest-bearing obligations and the same may be
sold for cash and for a sum not less than their current market price.
(Ord. 65-3. Passed 1-28-65.)
252.05  TREASURY INVESTMENT ACCOUNT.
   There is hereby established a Treasury Investment Account in which the
Finance and Revenue Director shall enter all transactions relating to the
investment of funds as provided in this chapter and shall maintain a record
showing all such investments, the date of purchase, the purchase price and
related information, including the interest rate and maturity date.  From time
to time, as such investments mature or interest is payable thereon, the
Director shall issue an order for their collection and deposit as hereinafter
provided.  All such securities shall be held and maintained under the custody
and control of the Director in a safe deposit box at the regular Municipal
depository and the same shall be opened only in the presence of the Mayor, the
Clerk-Treasurer and/or the Solicitor and only upon the order of the Clerk-
Treasurer directing the deposit or removal of securities.
252.06  DISPOSITION OF EARNINGS.
   (a)   Effective July 1, 1999, the Finance and Revenue Director is hereby
authorized to distribute interest income earned on all investment, savings and
checking accounts to the following Funds, based on revenues generated during
fiscal year 1998, rounded up to the nearest full percentage point:
      Fund 110 - General Fund   90%
      Fund 222 - S.C.M.R. Fund   5%
      Fund 223 - Motor Vehicle License Tax Fund   1%
      Fund 224 - State Highway Fund   1%
      Fund 230 - Northwood Waste/Environmental Fund   1%
      Fund 236 - Special Law Enforcement Fund   1%
      Fund 702 - Sanitary Sewer OMR Fund   1%
   Fund 236 (Special Law Enforcement Fund) shall receive interest from the date
of deposit of forfeiture funds and the transferred balance from the Police
Department checking account, pro-rated for the month of June, 1999.
(Ord. 99-22.  Passed 6-24-99.)
   (b)   The distribution of earned interest income as set forth in subsection
(a) hereof shall be subject to annual review by Council.
(Ord. 96-3.  Passed 2-22-96.)
252.07  REPORTS.
   From time to time, as directed by the Mayor or by Council, the Finance and
Revenue Director shall make a report to the Mayor and to Council respecting the
status of the Treasury Investment Account and all particulars respecting the
investment or proposed investment of such Municipal funds.

CHAPTER 270
Recreation Board; Parks
270.01   Establishment; composition.
270.02   Powers and duties.
270.03   Meetings.
270.04   Appointment; term.
270.05   Vacancies.
270.06   Officers; rules and regulations.
270.07   Budget.
270.08   Donations and bequests.
270.09   Disbursement of funds; approval of expenditures.
270.10   Baseball Commissioner.
270.11   Parks.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Land appropriation for parks - see Ohio R.C. 715.21, 719.01
   State law provisions - see Ohio R.C. 755.12 et seq.
270.01  ESTABLISHMENT; COMPOSITION.
   There shall be a Recreation Board consisting of five members, each of whom
shall be a resident and qualified elector of the City. The members shall
appointed by the Mayor with the consent of Council. Two of the members of the
Recreation Board shall be members of the Board of Education or shall be members
appointed by the Board of Education.
(Ord. 63-8. Passed 3-14-63; Ord. 2008-30.  Passed 12-4-08.)
270.02  POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Recreation Board shall generally act in an advisory capacity, making
recommendations to Council concerning the development, maintenance and
operation of playgrounds, recreational facilities, and programs for the City,
including fees and rates thereof. The Recreation Board shall also have those
powers and perform those duties as Council may provide by ordinance or
resolution, including, specifically, the following powers and duties:
   (a)   To analyze community needs in the parks and recreation area, and
recommend such programs, activities, and improvements as might be deemed
necessary to Council.
   (b)   To plan for both long-range and short-range expansions and changes in
parks, park facilities and make such recommendations to Council.
   (c)   To recommend rules and regulations governing the use of parks and
recreation facilities, such as: closing hours, restrictions on use, and
guidelines for use of parks and recreation facilities, subject to the approval
by legislation of Council.
   (d)   To recommend rates and fees for recreational activities and
facilities, subject to approval by legislation of Council.
   (e)   To review and make recommendations to Council concerning the need for
capital outlays, or the acquisition of major pieces of equipment in the area of
parks and recreation.
   (f)   To recommend the purchase, lease, sale, or exchange of real or
personal property in the name of the City, no longer needed for recreational
purposes, within or outside the City, subject to approval of Council.
   (g)   The Board shall devise and recommend for adoption by Council a
recreational program for children, young people, and men and women in all walks
of life; offer leadership in coordinating and correlating all recreational
activities to the maximum benefit of the citizens of the City; and cooperate
and coordinate the building of the total community recreational program into
and around the public and private organizations concerned with public welfare,
education, and family relations.
   (h)   To recommend the hiring of umpire-in-chiefs or providers of services
deemed necessary or desirable to carry out the programs and duties as outlined
herein, subject to approval by Council.
(Ord. 63-8. Passed 3-14-63; Ord. 2008-30.  Passed 12-4-08.)
270.03  MEETINGS.
   The Recreation Board shall hold a meeting at least once a month at a regular
scheduled place and time, and at other such times as may be necessary in the
judgment of the Chairperson or upon application to the Chairperson by at least
two members of the Board. Notice of each special meeting shall be given to the
members personally by telephone or e-mail notification at least 24 hours prior
to the time of the meeting, unless the member shall specifically waive notice
in writing or by actual attendance. All meetings of the Board shall be public.
(Ord. 2008-30.  Passed 12-4-08.)
270.04  APPOINTMENT; TERM.
   The members of the Recreation Board shall be appointed by the Mayor with the
concurrence of Council and shall serve for terms of five years, except that the
members first appointed shall be appointed for such terms that the term of one
member expires annually on December 31 thereafter.
(Ord. 63-8. Passed 3-14-63; Ord. 2008-30.  Passed 12-4-08.)
270.05  VACANCIES.
   Vacancies in the membership of the Recreation Board occurring otherwise than
by expiration of term shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner
as original appointments are made.
(Ord. 63-8. Passed 3-14-63; Ord. 2008-30.  Passed 12-4-08.)
270.06  OFFICERS; RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   Upon appointment and confirmation as hereinbefore provided, the members of
the Recreation Board shall elect a Chairman and Secretary and select all other
necessary officers to serve for a period of one year.  Such Board may adopt
rules and regulations for the conduct of all business within its jurisdiction.
(Ord. 63-8. Passed 3-14-63; Ord. 2008-30.  Passed 12-4-08.)
270.07  BUDGET.
   The Board shall, on or before September 15 of each year, submit to Council a
proposed budget and report of the program and activities proposed to be carried
on under the jurisdiction of the Board for the next succeeding fiscal year and
shall annually, on or before December 31, make and file with Council a complete
report of its activities for the past year, showing expenditures made and
obligations incurred together with any recommendations deemed pertinent to the
activities, facilities or business under the jurisdiction of the Board.
(Ord. 63-8. Passed 3-14-63; Ord. 2008-30.  Passed 12-4-08.)
270.08  DONATIONS AND BEQUESTS.
   The Recreation Board may solicit or receive gifts, donations or bequests of
money or property to be used for any activity or purpose within its
jurisdiction, subject to the approval of occupancy and the loan of facilities
and equipment to be used or employed for activities under its jurisdiction.
(Ord. 63-8. Passed 3-14-63; Ord. 2008-30.  Passed 12-4-08.)
270.09  DISBURSEMENT OF FUNDS, APPROVAL OF EXPENDITURES.
   (a)   Expenditures from funds appropriated by Council for activities within
the jurisdiction of the Recreation Board, after certification by the Board to
the Finance and Revenue Director of the amounts and purposes thereof, shall be
disbursed in the manner provided for disbursement of Municipal funds by the
laws of the State and the ordinances of the City.
   (b)   All expenditures from appropriate funds, other than compensation for
part- time employees, shall first be approved by Council upon the basis of
vouchers duly prepared and submitted for such purpose.
(Ord. 2008-30.  Passed 12-4-08.)
270.10  BASEBALL COMMISSIONER.
   There is hereby created the position, on a part-time basis, of Baseball
Commissioner, who shall be responsible for the administration, supervision,
scheduling and other required activities as prescribed by the Recreational
Board for the summer softball and baseball programs.
(Ord. 79-26. Passed 5-24-79; Ord. 2008-30.  Passed 12-4-08.)
270.11  PARKS.
   (a)   Hours.  All parks shall be open to the public every day sunrise to
sunset and during all hours which may be posted by the City, except in the case
of an emergency unforeseen occurrence.
   (b)   Special Function Time Extension. Permission for any special function
or special activity expected to extend beyond the normal closing hours can be
obtained if a written request is made therefor at least seven days in advance
of the planned activity and if written authority is granted by the City
Administrator.
   (c)   Park Closings. City Council may close any section or part of any park
to the public upon recommendation of the Recreation Board or upon Council's own
motion either temporarily or at regular and stated intervals in order to
properly conduct the activities of such park area. In cases of emergency or
safety, the City Administrator may temporarily close any park or section
thereof until the matter can be brought before the next regularly scheduled
Council meeting.
(Ord. 2008-30.  Passed 12-4-08.)

Civil Service Commission

   CROSS REFERENCES

Art. IX
   Establishment - see CHTR. Sec.
10.01
   Civil Service Commission - see CHTR. Sec.
10.02
   Civil service examinations for police officers - see ADM.
248.10
278.01  RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE:  The following rules and regulations were promulgated by the
Civil Service Commission pursuant to law and were formally adopted by Council
by Ordinance 94-18, passed February 10, 1994, and amended by Ordinance 2000-36,
passed December 7, 2000, Ordinance 2004-11, passed April 8, 2004, Ordinance
2013-34, passed December 12, 2013, and Ordinance 2017-08, passed April 27,
2017. Their inclusion herein was formally authorized by such ordinance.)
PREAMBLE
The following Rules and Regulations are adopted in accordance with the
authority conferred upon the Municipal Civil Service Commission of the City of
Northwood, Ohio, under the authority of the Charter and Ordinances of the City
of Northwood, Ohio, and Chapter 124 of the Ohio Revised Code.
CHAPTER ONE
GENERAL PROVISIONS
1-01  Structure of the Commission
The Municipal Civil Service of the City of Northwood, Ohio shall consist of
three (3) electors of the Municipality, not holding other public office,
appointed by the Mayor,  subject to confirmation by a majority of the members
of Council. Such appointments shall be on alternate years for staggered terms
of six (6) years as provided in R.C. 124.40. A vacancy occurring during the
term shall be filled in the manner provided for an original appointment.
1-02  Duties of the Commission
It shall be the duty of each member of the Commission to attend all meetings of
the Commission and to devote as much time as is necessary to the management of
the business and affairs of the Commission. The Commission shall administer and
enforce the Civil Service Laws of the State of Ohio, and the Rules and
Regulations herein prescribed relative to Civil Service in the City of
Northwood, Ohio.
1-03  Officers and Agents of the Commission
A.   The Commission shall elect one of its members as Chairman and one as Co-
Chairman, who shall serve until a new member is appointed and qualified, at 
which time successors as Chairman and Co-Chairman shall be elected. It shall 
be the duty of the Chairman or the Co-Chairman in his or her absence to do the
following:
      1.   to call such meetings of the Commission as are necessary to transact
the business and affairs of the Commission;
      2.   to sign the minutes of all action taken by the Commission;
      3.   to preside at all meetings of the Commission;
      4.   to insure that the Annual Report, as required by R.C. 124.40, is
assembled and transmitted to the State Personnel Board of Review in a timely
manner.
B.   The Commission shall employ or appoint a suitable person to act as
Secretary  to the Commission. This Secretary to the Commission need not be a
Commission member, but in any case, shall function as a fiduciary or agent  for
the Commission, and shall perform the following duties:
      1.   attend all the meetings of the Commission and keep the minutes
thereof:
      2.   keep in the form of minutes a record of the official actions of the 
Commission:
      3.   be available for the purpose of receiving calls, accepting service
of filings, and providing access to Commission records:
      4.   accurately and properly keep all of the records of the Commission;
      5.   keep all files in proper order;
      6.   prepare and deliver, or cause to be delivered, notices and other
communications ordered by the Commission;
      7.   properly furnish appointing authorities with eligibility lists;
      8.   maintain an official roster;
      9.   handle such correspondence as the Commission shall determine,
including the preparation of the annual report;
      10.   make available to the public those documents deemed to be public
records  under the terms of R.C. 149.43;
      11.   perform other duties as assigned by the Chairman.
C.   The Civil Service Commission may designate special examiners or contract
for the preparation or administration of examinations.
1-04  Powers and Duties of Commission
The Commission shall prescribe, amend and enforce rules for the classification
of positions in the Civil Service of the City; for examinations and
resignations therefor; for appointments, promotions, removals, transfers,
layoffs, suspensions, reductions and reinstatements therein; and for
standardizing positions and maintaining efficiency therein. In accordance with
R.C. 124.40 the Commission shall exercise the powers and perform the duties
conferred upon the Director of Administrative Services and the State Personnel
Board of Review, which include:
A.   To hear appeals, as provided by law, of employees in the classified
service from final decisions of appointing authorities relative to reduction in
pay or position,  job abolishments, layoff, suspension, fine, or discharge, or
final decisions of the appointing authority or the Civil Service Commission
relative to assignment or reassignment to a new or different position
classification or a refusal to reclassify the employee's position; however,
adverse actions based on certain felony convictions may not be appealed, per
R.C. 124.34(A); furthermore, an employee may not file a second appeal from a
decision of the Commission that originally resulted from an appeal — although
the Commission may allow timely motions for reconsideration; the Commission may
affirm, disaffirm or  modify a decision of the appointing authority as the case
may be, and its decision shall be final;
B.   To hear appeals of employees under R.C. 4167.13 relating to Occupational
Safety and Health.
C.   To hear appeals, as provided by law, of appointing authorities relative to
the  classification or reclassification of positions in the classified
service.  The  Commission may affirm, disaffirm or modify any such decision,
and its decision  shall be final;
D.   To appoint a secretary and such other employees necessary in the exercise
of the powers and performance of the duties and functions which the Commission
is by law authorized and required to exercise and perform and to prescribe the
duties of such secretary and employees:
E.   To maintain a journal, which shall be open to public inspection, in which
the Commission shall  keep a record of all of its proceedings and of the vote
of each of its members upon every action taken by it, along with a record of
the Commission's final decisions pertaining to the  classification or
reclassification of positions in the classified service of the City, and the
assignment  or reassignment of employees to specific position  classifications;
F.   To adopt and promulgate rules and regulations relating to the procedure of
the  Commission in administering the laws which it has authority or duty to 
administer and for the purpose of invoking the jurisdiction of the Commission 
in hearing appeals of appointing authorities and employees in  matters set
forth  in subsections A. and B. hereof;
G.   To subpoena and require the attendance and testimony of witnesses and the 
production of books, papers, public records and other documentary evidence
pertinent to any matter which it has authority to investigate, inquire into or 
hear in the same manner and to the same extent as provided by R.C. 124.09(G),
and all witness fees shall be paid in the manner set forth therein;
H.   To prepare, conduct and grade or contract for the preparation and
administration of all competitive examinations for positions in the classified
service;
I.   To prepare, conduct and grade or contract for the preparation and 
administration of all noncompetitive examinations for positions in the
classified service;
J.   To prepare eligible lists containing the names of persons qualified for
appointment to positions in the classified service;
K.   To prepare or amend specifications, description of duties,
responsibilities,  requirements and desirable qualifications of the various
classifications of positions in the municipal service;
L.   To allocate and reallocate upon its own motion or upon request of an
appointing authority any position, office or employment in the municipal
service to the appropriate classification on the basis of the duties,
responsibilities, requirements and qualifications of such position, office or
employment; assign related classifications, which form a career progression, to
a classification series;
M.   To develop and conduct personnel recruitment services for positions in the
municipal service;
N.   To conduct research on specifications, classifications and salaries of
positions  in the municipal service;
O.   To develop and conduct personnel training programs in cooperation with
appointing authorities;
P.   To enter into agreements for in-service training of personnel in the
municipal  service;
Q.   To appoint such examiners, inspectors, clerks and other assistants are
necessary in the exercise of the powers and performance of the duties and
functions  which the Commission is by law authorized and required to exercise
and perform, and to prescribe the duties of all such employees;
R.   To keep records of its proceedings and records of all applications for 
examinations and all examinations conducted by it;
S.   To prepare, continue and keep in the office of the Commission, a complete
roster of all persons in the classified service. This roster shall be open to
public inspection at all reasonable hours. It shall show in reference to each
of such persons, his or her name, the date of his or her appointment to or
employment in such service, his or her pay grade, the title of the place or
office which he or she holds, the nature of the duties thereof, and, in case of
his or her removal or resignation, the date of the termination of such service;
T.   To make investigations concerning all matters affecting the enforcement
and administration of R.C. Chapter 124 and the rules of the Commission
prescribed herein. In the course of such investigations, the Commission or its
designee may administer oaths and affirmations, and take testimony relative to
any matter which the Commission has authority to investigate;
U.   To make a report to the Mayor on or before the first day of January of
each year, showing its own actions, the rules and all exceptions thereto in
force, and any recommendations for the more effectual accomplishment of the
purposes of Civil Service in the City. The Commission shall also furnish any
special reports to the Mayor whenever the same are requested by him. Such
reports shall be printed for public distribution under the same regulations as
are the reports of other officers, boards or commissions;
V.   To make an annual report and other reports as may be necessary to the
State  Personnel Board of Review in accordance with R.C. 124.40.
W.   Hearing Officer/Trial Board:  The Commission may designate persons to
serve as Special Hearing Officers or a Trial Board under its direction, with
such compensation as may be agreed between the persons so employed and the
Commission.
1-05  Agent for Filing and Service
   The Commission may designate an individual in the office of the Municipal 
Administrator, who shall be empowered to accept filings and service of 
documents, on behalf of the Commission.
1-06  Meetings of the Commission
A.   All meetings of the Civil Service Commission are open to the public except
as set forth in R.C. 121.22 and this rule.
B.   General minutes shall be taken at all Civil Service Commission meetings
and shall be open to public inspection.
C.   The Chairman may, on his own initiative, and shall, upon the request of
the other two (2) members of the Commission, call a special meeting of the
Commission, to be held not later than ten (10) working days from the date of
notice of such meeting. In the absence of the Chairman, the Co-Chairman shall
act as Chairman. Two (2) members of the Commission shall constitute a quorum at
any meeting of the Commission, and it shall require the affirmative vote of at
least two (2) members to adopt any motion or resolution.
D.   Notice of any meeting of the Civil Service Commission must be posted at
the municipal building not less than twenty-four (24) hours in advance of the
meeting.
E.   In the event of an emergency, the Chairman or members calling the meeting
must immediately post a statement concerning the time, place and purpose of the
meeting.
F.   An executive session may be held only after a majority of the members, by
roll call vote, have approved such action. Such executive session may be
convened to consider the appointment, employment, dismissal, discipline,
promotion, demotion or compensation of a municipal employee, unless such
employee requests a public hearing. The motion and vote to hold the executive
session shall state which one or more of these purposes are the purposes for
which the executive session is being held, but need not name the person who is
to be considered during the session.  Executive session may also be held for
other reasons enumerated in R.C. 121.22 and the other laws and regulations
incorporated therein.  Minutes of any executive session shall be appropriate to
the nature of such executive session.
G.   The order of business for meetings of the Commission shall be:
   1.    roll call;
   2.   disposition of unapproved minutes;
   3.   unfinished business;
   4.   reports;
   5.   new business;
   6.   adjournment.
1-07  Procedure for the Adoption, Amendment or Rescission of Rules
A.   Public notice as to the adoption, amendment, or rescission of any rule of
the Civil Service Commission must be given to a newspaper of local circulation
a reasonable time prior to the date set for hearing and consideration of the
rule. Revisions following the initial notification are not subject to the
notice requirement and may be agreed upon at the Commission meeting.
B.   The public notice must contain a statement of the Commission's intention
to alter or adopt a rule, and a statement as to the subject matter of the rule
to be affected. In addition, the notice must contain the date, time and place
set for the consideration of the rule change.
C.   A copy of the full text of any proposed rule or rule change shall be
submitted to the Mayor at least two (2) days prior to the date set for
consideration.
D.   Civil Service Commission rules shall be adopted by a majority vote and
entered into  the minutes. Interested parties may provide input in writing,
preferably in advance, or offer written or oral input at the meeting(s) called
to consider the rules or rule changes.  Civil Service Commission rules, once
adopted by a majority vote and entered into the minutes, will be submitted to
City Council for adoption as an ordinance.  Copies of the rules or rule
changes, together with the minutes of the Civil  Service Commission adopting
the change and a copy of the ordinance enacting the change, will be kept by the
designee of the Commission and made available  to any person upon request. Due
notice of the contents of such rules and of all changes shall be given to
appointing authorities affected by such rules, and such rules shall be printed
for public distribution.
1-08  Scope of the Rules
A.   These rules shall be applicable to all civil service matters, except to
the extent these rules have been superseded by collective bargaining agreements
between the City of Northwood and a public employee collective bargaining
representative, or by Charter or ordinance.
B.   No person shall be appointed, removed, transferred, laid off, suspended,
reinstated, promoted, or reduced as an officer or employee in the Civil Service
of the City of Northwood, Ohio in any manner or by any means other than those
prescribed in these rules, except as provided in (A) above.
1-09  Construction
A.   These rules should be construed so as to carry out their purposes as
determined from both the literal reading of the rules and their context.  The
rules should be construed and applied in a manner that is consistent with the
laws of the State of Ohio, except to the extent that the letter or context of
the City Charter or City ordinances indicate that the City intended to
supersede, preempt, or otherwise override state law through a valid exercise of
Home Rule.  The rules should not be construed so as to limit the City's power
to exercise Home Rule, except to the extent that the City has limited itself in
the City Charter.  Nor should the rules be construed in a way that limits the
Civil Service Commission's power to interpret and apply the rules within the
scope of their lawful authority.
B.   A Charter provision will prevail over any conflicting ordinance.  An
ordinance will prevail over any conflicting rule.  Any applicable collective
bargaining agreement that provides for binding arbitration of grievances and
that conflicts with the Charter, an ordinance, or these rules will prevail over
any of the foregoing, pursuant to Chapter 4117 of the Ohio Revised Code, unless
the subject matter is not a proper subject for collective bargaining.  In
particular, persons convicted of certain felonies under R.C. 124.34 lose
certain rights notwithstanding any collective bargaining agreement.
CHAPTER TWO
DEFINITIONS
2-01  Definitions
Whenever used in the Civil Service Rules and Regulations the terms listed below
shall be construed as follows:
A.   “Allocation” means the determination by the Commission of the class to
which a position belongs.
B.   “Applicant” means a person requesting consideration for examination and
employment in a class in the classified service of the City.
C.   “Appointing Authority” means the officer, commission, board, or body
having the power of appointment to, or removal from, positions in any office,
department, commission, or board, and shall include but not be limited to the
following:
   1.   Mayor
   2.   Municipal Administrator
D.   “Available Vacancy” means an existing funded position not currently filled
by an  incumbent which the appointing authority desires to fill. The existence
of vacant positions on an appointing authority's table of organization shall
not mean that a position is an available vacancy.
E.   “Certification” means the act of certifying and supplying names from an
official eligible list (and recording thereon) to the appointing authority for
purposes of employment selection or layoff.
F.   “Certified Eligible List” means an official list certified and issued to
an appointing authority of individuals available for employment from an
eligible list.
G.   “Civil Service” includes all officers and positions of trust or employment
in the  service of the City of Northwood, Ohio.
H.   “Class” is used to designate one or more positions sufficiently distinct
from all other positions in duties, responsibilities and qualifications
required to warrant a separate title.
I.   “Classification” means a class as provided in subsection (H) hereof or
the  process by which the proper title and level for each position is
determined.
J.   “Classified service” comprises all persons in the employ of the City,
except those who are specifically included in the unclassified service per
Charter Section
9.02.
K.   “Commission” means the Municipal Civil Service Commission of the City of
Northwood, Ohio.
L.   “Competitive examination” means an examination given for the purpose of
determining the relative rank of those qualifying and establishing an eligible
list arranged in the order of placement as a result of an examination procedure
and these rules.
M.   “Day” means calendar days unless otherwise specified.
N.   “Demotion” means, except as otherwise provided herein or in R.C. Chapter
124, the movement of an employee from a position in one class to a position in 
another class having a lower maximum salary rate.
O.   “Eligible” means a person who has made application for appointment to a
classification, has satisfactorily met all qualifications and requirements for
employment in the job class for which the person has made application, has
passed an examination for that class, and whose name appears on an eligible 
list as provided in Chapter Seven of these rules.
P.   “Eligible list” means a list of names of persons found qualified either
through examinations or reemployment procedure for the purpose of filling
vacancies in  the classified service for a particular job class.
Q.   “Employee” means any person holding a position subject to appointment,
removal, promotion or reduction by an appointing officer.
R.   “Examination” means any exercise or procedure which serves to provide an
evaluation of an individual's qualifications or fitness for a particular
position.
S.   Exempt Appointment” means an appointment to a position which is not
subject to an examination or civil service tenure.
T.   “Municipal Service” shall include those positions in the classified
service of the City of Northwood, Ohio.
U.   “Non-competitive examination” means an open examination, given to
determine those qualified to fill appointments to positions requiring peculiar
and exceptional qualifications of a scientific, professional, educational or
managerial character or positions where it is impractical to develop and
administer competitive examinations.
V.   “Notice” means the mailing by regular U.S. mail (or by certified mail -
- see special provisions within certain rules) addressed to the latest address
provided in writing to the Commission by the person to be notified or by actual
delivery to the person or entity of any notice required under these rules.
W.   “Open competitive” or “competitive entrance” examination means an 
examination open to all persons, whether employed by the City or not, who meet
the qualifications and comply with the prescribed requirements for  admission
thereto.
X.   “Permanent employee” means any employee in the classified service who,
following certification, has completed the applicable probationary period and
occupies a duly authorized position involving year-round service.
Y.   “Position” means any office, employment or job calling for the performance
of certain duties and the exercise of certain responsibilities by one
individual. A position may be vacant, occupied part-time or occupied full-time.
Z.   “Position classification” means the arrangement of positions into classes
including grades. Positions shall be classified in accordance with the duties
and responsibilities of the position.
AA.   “Promotion” means the movement of an employee from a position in one
class to another position having a higher maximum salary rate.
BB.   “Promotional competitive examination” means a competitive examination
which is open only to current employees who meet the qualification and
eligibility requirements set forth.
CC.   “Provisional employee” means a type of temporary employee filling a duly 
authorized position without competition pending the establishment of an
eligible list.
DD.   “Specification” means a general description of a job classification
specifying or  giving examples of the kinds of tasks expected to be performed
by employees holding positions allocated to that classification; which may
include  classification title and number, a statement of job functions, a
grouping of task statements by job duties (ranked by importance), approximate
percentages of total job time required for the performance of each duty, worker
characteristics or behaviors required for successful completion of all tasks
within each duty, and minimum qualifications for competition for employment in
the classification.
EE.   “Status” means the nature or type of employment held by a City employee
under the classified service of the City.
FF.   “Unclassified service” comprises those positions set forth in the Charter
of the Municipality of Northwood, Ohio at Sec.
9.01. Positions in the unclassified service shall be exempt from all
examinations required by law or these rules.
GG.   “Weights” means the relative importance of the subjects or parts of an 
examination as expressed in percentages, proportions or ratios as determined by
the Commission.
HH.   The masculine pronoun “he” and its derivatives, whenever employed,
include the  feminine pronoun and its derivatives. The singular number shall
include the plural, and its derivatives. The singular number shall include the
plural, and the plural shall include the singular.
CHAPTER THREE
CLASSIFICATION
3-01  Classification
A.   The Civil Service Commission shall establish, and may modify or repeal, by
rule,  a job classification plan for all classified positions, officers and
employment situations in the employ of the City of Northwood, Ohio.
B.   Positions in the Civil Service of the City shall be classified in
accordance with the classification plan, which shall provide that any and all
positions whose duties, responsibilities, and necessary qualifications are
sufficiently alike to so warrant shall be allocated to the same class with a
title which shall be descriptive of the duties performed.
C.   Class Series
   The Civil Service Commission may designate a class series to be made up of
job  classes having related functions that form a career progression.
3-02  Class Specification
A class specification shall be prepared for each job classification setting
forth a class title, salary range, typical duties and responsibilities, and the
necessary qualifications. This class specification shall set forth the factors
and conditions which are essential characteristics of the class and also those
factors or conditions which differentiate it from other classes.
3-03  Reclassification
A.   Whenever a new position is established or the duties of a position are so
changed that the statement of duties and typical tasks of the class to which it
was originally allocated no longer applies, the appointing authority shall
report such fact to the Commission and transmit a full statement of the
circumstances and description of the duties. The Commission shall thereupon,
after investigation, determine the proper classification of such position. The
Commission shall from time to time make an investigation of all positions in
the  service to determine whether such positions are allocated to the proper
classifications. Any employee or his authorized representative or any
appointing authority desiring to submit facts for consideration of the
Commission shall be afforded reasonable opportunity to do so. When the
Commission finds improper classifications of positions exist the Commission may
reallocate any position to the appropriate class as is necessary to provide an
equitable, just and proper classification.
B.    Any employee may request a review of the classification of his position
for the  purposes of determining whether the position is properly classified.
The  Commission shall give proper consideration to such request.
3-04  Notification of Employees
Whenever the classification title of a position is changed other than by
promotion or  demotion, the Commission shall notify in writing, any employee
affected by the  change as well as the employee's appointing authority.
3-05  Specification Amendments
Where particular licenses or attributes, such as insurability, are essential
characteristics or functions of a position, the class series specification may
be amended to so reflect. Such amendments may be requested by the appointing
authority or may  be made independently by the Civil Service Commission, and
must be reflected on the  minutes of the Commission.
CHAPTER FOUR
APPLICATIONS
4-01  How Made
All applications, whether for employment or for examination, must be made
under  oath or affirmation and upon forms prescribed by the Civil Service
Commission. All application forms must be completed in their entirety and
printed legibly in ink (by  the person unless such person is disabled, in which
case “reasonable accommodation” will be made) and submitted to the Civil
Service Commission in a timely manner. The application forms of individuals who
successfully complete applications will be retained by the Civil Service
Commission for two (2) years.  Applications for such persons who are placed on
eligible lists shall be retained by the Civil Service Commission during the
effective period of the eligible list or for two (2) years, whichever is
greater.  The application forms of individuals who are appointed to or employed
in any classified civil service position shall be retained by the Civil Service
Commission during the tenure of said employee.  After the expiration of any of
the foregoing retention periods, the Commission will retain or dispose of the
records in accordance with the procedures established by the Records
Commission.
The Commission shall make reasonable accommodations available to otherwise
qualified persons with disabilities to afford them access to the application
and examination process.
4-02  Forms
At the first meeting of the Civil Service Commission following January 1 of
each  year, the Commission will review the prescribed form or forms, make any
changes  that are deemed necessary, and, by majority vote, approve the form or
forms to be used for the next ensuing year.
Application forms shall be available in the office of the Commission or at
other locations as announced by the Civil Service Commission. To the extent
that the same are reasonably necessary in the application process, the Civil
Service Commission may require of applicants such references as to the
character of the applicant provided by persons having knowledge of the same as
the Commission may require.
4-03  Residency
Every applicant for a position in the classified service must be a citizen of
the United States, or must legally declare and signify in writing his or her
intention to become, upon appointment, a citizen of the United States.
Furthermore, every such applicant must be a resident of the state of Ohio or
signify in writing his or her intention to become and remain, upon appointment,
a resident of Ohio within six (6) months, unless such requirements are
specifically waived by Charter, ordinance, or statute; except that no residency
requirement applies to temporary or exceptional appointments (see Chapter 8 for
a description of such appointments).
4-04  Disqualification of Applicants
The Commission may refuse to examine, or, after an examination, refuse to
certify as eligible, or after certification revoke that certification, of any
person: who is found to lack any of the established preliminary requirements
for the examination; who is physically so disabled as to be rendered unfit for
the performance of the duties of the position which he seeks, who is addicted
to the habitual use of intoxicating liquors or drugs to excess, who has been
convicted of a felony, theft offense, domestic violence including lesser
included offenses, job-related non-traffic non-juvenile misdemeanors less than
seven (7) years old, repeated D.U.I.s, D.U.I. within the last three (3) years,
extensive moving violations, i.e. over six (6) points within the last three (3)
years; who has been issued a permanent civil protection order; who is
uninsurable; who has been guilty of infamous or notoriously disgraceful 
conduct, who has been dismissed from either branch of the civil service for
delinquency or misconduct, or who has made false statements of any material
fact, or practiced, or attempted to practice, any deception or fraud in his or
her application or in his or her examination, in establishing his or her
eligibility, or securing his or her appointment. In relation to such inquiries
the Civil Service Commission may require such certificates of persons having
knowledge of the applicant as the good of the civil service may require,
subject to the requirements of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, if and to the
extent those provisions are applicable.  The Commission may also take into
consideration that convictions (e.g., for misdemeanors) are more than seven (7)
years old.
4-05  Age and Peace Officer Certification Restrictions for Police
A.   Minimum Age for Application: 
Applicants for original appointment examination in the Police Department must
have attained the age of twenty-one (21) years on or before the last date
applications to take the test are accepted.
B.   Peace Officer Certification and Education Requirements: 
   1.   No application for entry level police civil service testing will be
accepted unless the candidate can offer proof that, at the time of application,
he or she does possess an Associate’s Degree or completion of 96 quarter hours
or 64 semester hours towards a Bachelor's Degree from an accredited college or
university; or education may be substituted with five (5) years of continuous
active full-time experience as a law enforcement officer with a Federal, State,
County or Municipal Agency or Department, and at time of appointment, he or she
is currently certified for peace officer employment as per Ohio R.C. 109.75 and
109.77.
   2.   In the event that there are fewer than ten (10) candidates qualified
for testing under paragraph (B)(1) hereof, the Civil Service Commission may
waive the certification requirement for any candidate who has signed and
tendered to the Civil Service Commission a “Contract for Reimbursement of
Hiring and Training Expenses,” a copy of which is attached to original
Ordinance 95-26, passed May 25, 1995, and incorporated as if set forth herein.
   3.   Unless an emergency is jointly declared by the Mayor or the Municipal
Administrator, and the Civil Service Commission, no peace officer shall be
hired by the City except as set forth in paragraph (B)(1) or (2) hereof.
      In the event that any part of this section is held invalid or
unenforceable, the remainder shall remain in full force and effect.
      In the event that paragraph (B)(2) hereof is held to be invalid or
unenforceable by any court, agency, or arbitrator, all employees hired under
paragraph (B)(2) hereof will be immediately determined to have been
“unqualified” and unlawfully appointed and will be immediately discharged based
upon noncompliance with paragraph (B)(1) hereof.  (See Chapter 10 of these
rules regarding procedures for removal.)
      This rule is intended to prevail over any other rules governing the same
subject matter covered herein.
4-06  Promotional Restrictions: Police
A.   Vacancies above the rank of patrolman in the Police Department shall be
filled by promotion from among persons serving with the Northwood Police
Department holding the next immediately lower rank after passing a competitive
promotional examination.
B.   Whenever a vacancy occurs in the promoted ranks of the Police Department,
no  person shall be eligible to take the promotional examination unless he or
she has served at least forty-eight (48) months in the lower rank with at least
thirty-six (36) of these months served in the Northwood Police Department.  No
competitive promotional examination shall be held unless there are at least two
(2) persons eligible to compete.  If the Civil Service Commission determines
that there are less than two (2) persons holding positions in the rank next
lower than the position to be filled, who are eligible and willing to compete,
the Commission shall allow the persons holding positions in the then next lower
rank who are eligible, to compete with the persons holding positions in the
rank lower than the position to be filled.
C.   In the event that only one (1) person applies for a promotional
appointment examination, a provisional appointment may be made, provided that
the appointee otherwise meets the minimum qualifications. Such appointment need
not be the sole applicant for the promotional appointment examination.
D.   A person serving as a provisional employee who passes an examination for
the position which he or she holds, shall be appointed as a permanent certified
employee prior to the preparation of an eligible list by the Civil Service
Commission.
E.   Any provisional employee who remains in provisional status in the same
classification for a period of two (2) years of continuous service, during
which period no competitive examination is held, shall become a permanent
appointee in the classified service at the conclusion of such two (2) year
period.
4-07  Equal Employment Opportunity Applicant Flow Information
The Civil Service Commission shall design and approve for use a form to be used
in  documenting Equal Employment Opportunity applicant flow statistics.
This Equal Employment Opportunity applicant flow information sheet may be
furnished to all applicants for employment or examination.
The completion of the Equal Employment Opportunity applicant flow information
sheet by applicants for testing or employment shall be wholly voluntary, and
no  applicant shall be adversely affected in any way for having refused to
complete such form.
Once completed, Equal Employment Opportunity applicant flow information sheets
shall be physically separated from the application and separately filed as a 
confidential EEO compliance record.
CHAPTER FIVE
EXAMINATIONS
5-01  Examinations; Provisional Appointments
A.   Examinations for appointments must be competitive, and no such examination
will be administered unless there are at least two (2) applicants. All
applicants for positions in the classified civil service shall be subject to
examination.  However, where the Civil Service Commission determines that the
best interests of the civil service will be served by filling a vacancy through
reduction, transfer, reinstatement, or promotion without competition, the
vacancy will be filled by one of those methods, at the discretion of the Civil
Service Commission, rather than by examination and certification of names from
a list of eligibles.  (The rationale being that the person to be reduced,
transferred, promoted, or reinstated has presumably already demonstrated his or
her qualifications for the position.)  The reduction, transfer, reinstatement,
or promotion will be subject to the rules governing those actions.
   There shall be two basic types of examinations administered by the Civil
Service Commission in accordance with these rules:
   1.   examinations for original appointments;
   2.   examinations for promotion.
   Examinations for original appointments shall be open to all individuals who
otherwise qualify for appointment to or employment in a position under these
rules.  The Commission shall decide whether a position will be filled by
promotional examination, rather than open-competitive examination.  Vacancies
in positions in the classified service shall be filled insofar as practicable
by promotions.  The Commission may consult with the appointing authority when
making the determination.  The Commission may also hold a combined promotional
and open-competitive examination, resulting in two eligibility lists, of which
the promotional list shall have priority (see Eligibility Lists).
   If the examination is promotional, the Commission shall decide which classes
of employees may take the examination, whether the employees must be certified
in their current positions, and whether they must have completed their
probationary periods in order to compete.  The Commission may also determine
that other persons in the classified service are eligible to compete in a
promotional examination, if they otherwise meet the minimum qualifications for
the promotional position.  These provisions are subject to more specific time
in rank requirements for Police Department promotions.
   Examinations may include an evaluation of such factors as education,
training, capacity, knowledge, manual dexterity, physical or psychological
fitness, driving record, criminal record, job-related background, and/or
insurability .  Examinations may consist of one test, or of more than one test
in combination.  Tests may be written, oral, physical, demonstration of ability
to perform essential functions, or an evaluation of training and experience,
and shall be designed to fairly test the relative capacity of the persons
examined to discharge the particular duties of the position or classification
for which appointment is sought.  Where minimum or maximum requirements are
established for any examination, the same shall be specified in the examination
announcement.
B.   Examinations for appointments must be competitive, except as otherwise
provided herein, and no such examination will be administered unless there are
at least two (2) applicants. In the event that only one (1) person applies for
an original appointment examination, a provisional appointment may be made,
provided that the appointee otherwise meets the minimum qualifications. Such
appointment need not be the sole applicant for the original appointment
examination.
C.   A person serving as a provisional employee who passes an examination for
the position which he holds, shall be appointed as a permanent certified
employee prior to the preparation of an eligible list by the Civil Service
Commission.
D.   Any provisional employee who remains in provisional status in the same
classification for a period of two (2) years of continuous service, during
which period no competitive examination is held, shall become a permanent
appointee in the classified service at the conclusion of such two (2) year
period.
5-02  Examination Notices And Sites
A.   Examinations for original or promotional appointments shall be held at
such times and in such places as the Civil Service Commission deems
appropriate,  and shall be administered in accordance with the applicable
sections of R.C. Chapter 124 and these regulations.
B.   Printed public notice of each examination for original appointment in the
classified  service shall be given through the local newspapers and shall be
posted in conspicuous places in the City office buildings at least one (1) week
prior to the last date for filing application, and shall include the time,
place, and general scope of the competitive examination. In addition, the
Commission may cause the notice to be given or posted in such other places as
it may deem advisable.
C.   Notice of promotional examinations shall be posted in conspicuous places
in each department in which employees would be interested and eligible to
compete for such promotion. Such notices shall be posted at least one (1) week
prior to the last date for filing application, and shall include the time,
place and general scope of the competitive examination.
D.   Notices of all examinations for original appointments in the classified
service may also be distributed to such persons or organizations as the
Commission may deem to be interested in the positions to be filled.
5-03  Medical, Psychological, And Drug Testing
A.   Whenever physical or psychological qualifications are of special
importance, the applicants may be required to pass a physical or psychological
examination and be certified as qualified in such respects, whether before
admission to the examination, or before being placed on the appropriate
eligible list, or before certification for appointment, as the Commission may
deem advisable. Medical examinations will only be conducted after a prospective
appointee has received a conditional offer of employment; except that the
Commission may require that an applicant may be medically examined prior to any
test (e.g., a physical agility test) to determine the applicant's ability to
participate safely in the test.  When asking for such a medical opinion, the
Commission will describe the agility or fitness test, and ask “Can this person
safely perform this test?”  Examinations must be job- related and based on
business necessity. Police applicants may be required to take and pass physical
examinations as provided in R.C. 124.41. See also subsection 5.03(D) below.
B.   Such examinations may include a screening for the use of controlled
substances, which may include, among other things, hair testing.
C.   Physical, psychological, managerial skill, or drug screening examinations,
whenever required by the Commission or by these rules, the City Charter or R.C.
Chapter 124, shall be made by a licensed or certified professional designated
by the Commission, who shall furnish a certificate as to the applicant's
fitness for duty. The professional fee for such examinations shall not be borne
by the applicant.
D.    Physical Standards for Police
   The Civil Service Commission is authorized by law (R.C. 124.20) to establish
requirements for appointment to the Police Department.
   In addition to any other examination of employees under these rules, no
person will be eligible to receive an original appointment to the Police
Department as a police officer under the civil service laws, unless he or she
has, not more than one hundred twenty (120) days prior to appointment, passed a
physical examination, given by a licensed physician, certifying that the
applicant is free of cardiovascular and pulmonary diseases, and showing that he
or she meets the physical requirements necessary to perform the essential
functions of a police officer as established by the Civil Service Commission.
   The Commission will only have such an examination conducted after the
prospective appointee has received a conditional offer of employment.  The City
will pay the fee for the physical examination.  The appointing authority shall
file the report or findings of the licensed physician with the Police and
Firemen's Disability and Pension Fund within thirty (30) days of the date the
employee becomes a member of the fund (the latter usually being the date of
hire).
5-04  Admission of Applicants to Examination
A.   No applicant shall be admitted to any assembled examination more than
thirty (30) minutes after the advertised time of beginning such examination,
nor after any applicant competing in any such examination has completed his or
her work and left the examination room, whichever shall first occur, except by
special permission of the person in charge, who, in his discretion, may admit
the applicant conditionally, subject to the final approval or disapproval of
such admission by the Commission.
B.   Any applicant admitted to an assembled examination after its advertised
time of beginning must complete the examination at the advertised ending time,
and shall receive no extension time, except as set forth in
5-06, infra.
5-05  Identity of Entry Level Examinees Concealed
The identity of all persons taking competitive entry level assembled
examinations shall be concealed by the use of an identification number which
shall be used on all examination papers. This number shall be used from the
beginning of the examination until the papers have all been rated. Any papers
bearing the name of the applicant or any other identification mark shall be
rejected and the candidate so notified.
5-06  Extension of Time in Examination
   No applicant shall be given a longer time on any subject than prescribed by
the Commission for the completion of an examination.
   Separate time limits may be established as a reasonable accommodation to a
handicapped or disabled applicant.
   Requests for additional time, or accommodation, must be submitted with
supporting  documentation at the time of filing application for the
examination.
5-07  Visitors at Examinations
No visitors shall be admitted to the examination room during any examination
except by special permission of the person in charge.
5-08  Postponement or Cancellation of Examination
A scheduled examination may be cancelled or postponed by order of the Civil
Service  Commission, for any adequate reason. Reasonable efforts shall be made
to notify each  qualified applicant of the cancellation or postponement, and
will include written notice to the applicant's last known post office address.
5-09  Fraud Prohibited
Frauds in examinations are prohibited in accordance with R.C. 124.58.  No
person or officer shall:
A.   Willfully or corruptly by himself or herself in cooperation with one or
more persons defect, deceive, or obstruct any person in respect of their right
of examination, appointment, or employment arising under the Civil Service law
or any rules and regulations prescribed pursuant thereto: or
B.   Willfully or corruptly, falsely mark, grade, estimate or report upon the
examination or proper standing of any person examined, registered, or certified
pursuant to the provisions of the Civil Service Law, or aid in so doing; or,
C.   Willfully or corruptly make any false representations concerning the
results of such examinations of concerning any person examined.
