CHAPTER 810
Licenses Generally
810.01   Application of chapter.
810.02   License required.
810.03   Application for license.
810.04   Issuance.
810.05   Effective period.
810.06   Transferability.
810.07   Display of certificate.
810.08   Revocation or suspension.
810.09   Appeal and review.
810.99   Penalty.
810.01  APPLICATION OF CHAPTER.
   This chapter shall govern the licensing of the various trades, businesses
and professions regulated in this Title Two of Part Eight - the Business
Regulation and Taxation Code except to the extent that the same is governed by
other provisions in this Title Two.
810.02  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall engage in any of the trades, businesses or professions for
which licenses are required by this Title Two of Part Eight - the Business
Regulation and Taxation Code or by any other ordinance or provision of these
Codified Ordinances without first applying for and obtaining a license from the
Clerk-Treasurer or other duly authorized issuing authority.
(Ord. 63-1. Passed 1-3-63.)
810.03  APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   All original applications for licenses, unless otherwise specifically
provided, shall be made to the Clerk-Treasurer in writing upon forms to be
furnished by him and shall contain:
   (a)   The name of the applicant and of each officer, partner or business
associate;
   (b)   The applicant's present occupation and place of business;
   (c)   The applicant's place of residence for five years next preceding the
date of application;
   (d)   The nature and location of the intended business or enterprises;
   (e)   The period of time for which the license is desired;
   (f)   If for a vendor, a description of the merchandise to be sold; and
   (g)   Such other information concerning the applicant and his business as
may be reasonable and proper, having regard to the nature of the license
desired.
   Renewal of an annual license may be granted to a licensee in good standing
upon the original application, unless otherwise provided.
   With each original or renewal application, the applicant shall deposit the
fee required for the license requested.
   No person shall knowingly make any false statement or representation in such
application.
(Ord. 63-1. Passed 1-3-63.)
810.04  ISSUANCE.
   Upon receipt of such application for a license, accompanied by the proper
fee, if approval by another officer or department is not required, the Clerk-
Treasurer, by and with the written approval of the Mayor, or other chief
administrative officer, shall forthwith deposit the fee in the Treasury and
issue to the applicant a proper license certificate signed by such Clerk-
Treasurer and Mayor or other chief administrative officer. If for any reason
the license is not issued, the aforesaid deposit, less one dollar ($1.00) to
cover expenses of considering such application, shall be returned to the
applicant.
(Ord. 63-1. Passed 1-3-63. )
810.05  EFFECTIVE PERIOD.
   A license shall not be valid beyond the expiration date therein specified
and, unless otherwise provided, shall not extend beyond December 31 of the year
issued; except that at any time after December 14 licenses may be issued for
the ensuing calendar year. Unless otherwise specified the full annual fee will
be required of licensees irrespective of the date of issue of such license.
(Ord. 63-1. Passed 1-3-63. )
810.06  TRANSFERABILITY.
   Every license shall be issued to a real party in interest in the enterprise
or business and, unless otherwise provided, no license shall be assigned or
transferred.
(Ord. 63-1. Passed 1-3-63. )
810.07  DISPLAY OF CERTIFICATE.
   Every licensee carrying on business at a fixed location shall keep the
license certificate posted in a prominent place upon the licensed premises.
Other licensees shall carry their license certificates at all times and shall
exhibit the same whenever requested to do so by any officer or resident.
(Ord. 63-1. Passed 1-3-63.)
810.08  REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION.
   Any license may be revoked by the Mayor or other chief administrative
officer at any time for conditions or considerations which, had they existed at
the time of issuance, would have been valid grounds for its denial; for any
misrepresentation of a material fact in the application discovered after
issuance of the license; for violation of any provision of this chapter or
other law or ordinance relating to the operation of the business or enterprise
for which the license has been issued; or upon conviction of a licensee for a
violation of any Federal, State or municipal law or ordinance involving moral
turpitude. Such revocation shall become effective upon notice served upon such
licensee or posted upon the premises affected. As a preliminary to revocation,
the Mayor or other chief administrative officer may issue an order suspending
such license, which shall become effective immediately upon service of written
notice to such licensee. Such notice shall specify the reason for suspension
and may provide conditions under which reinstatement of the license may be
obtained. Upon compliance with such conditions within the time specified, such
license may be restored.
(Ord. 63-1. Passed 1-3-63. )
810.09  APPEAL AND REVIEW.
   In case any applicant has been denied a license, or if his license has been
revoked or suspended, the applicant or licensee, as the case may be, shall,
within three business days, have the right to appeal to Council from such
denial, revocation or suspension. Notice of appeal shall be filed in writing
with the Clerk-Treasurer who shall fix the time and place for hearing, the same
to be not later than one week thereafter. The Clerk-Treasurer shall notify the
Mayor and all members of Council of the time and place of such hearing not less
than twelve hours in advance thereof. Three members of Council shall constitute
a quorum to hear such appeal. The appellant may appear and be heard in person
or by counsel. If, after hearing, a majority of the members of Council present
at such meeting declares in favor of the applicant, such license shall be
forthwith issued or fully reinstated, as the case may be; otherwise the order
appealed from shall become final.
(Ord. 63-1. Passed 1-3-63.)
810.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100. 00). A separate
offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation
occurs or continues.
CHAPTER 812
Registration of Contractors and Tradesmen
812.01   General provisions - registration of contractors, home remodelers,
tradesmen and skilled tradesmen.
812.01   GENERAL PROVISIONS - REGISTRATION OF CONTRACTORS, HOME REMODELERS,
TRADESMEN AND SKILLED TRADESMEN.
   (a)   Registration of the following contractors, home remodelers, tradesmen
and/or skilled tradesmen prior to performance of work or rendering of services
within the City shall be required and no person, firm or corporation shall
conduct, render or ply construction services or trades within the City without
registration as set forth hereinafter.  Construction services and trades shall
include, but not limited to: electrical, plumbing, HVAC, steam fitting,
masonry, carpentry, blacktopping, roofing and similar services and such other
services as may be hereinafter designated by the City or its Administrator.
   (b)   No person, firm or corporation shall render services in the trades or
skills as set forth herein by displaying a sign advertising said services, or
advertising further by means of business cards, stationary, media
advertisement, trade or telephone listing or otherwise indicate or represent
either orally or in writing that he, they or it are in the commercial or
residential field for performance of services as set forth in this Code, unless
all of the requirements herein are met and further unless said individual,
business or corporation shall have obtained a registration certificate as
provided herein and the signs are in accordance with Section
1282.03 of the Northwood Codified Ordinance (Signs).
   (c)   No person, firm or corporation holding a registration certificate as
provided herein shall loan or extend the rights and privileges given under said
separate certificate for work contracted for or done by any other person other
than the person or persons registered or working under the direction or
supervision of said person as registered and upon notice of any violation by
the building officials of the City, such certificate shall be suspended or
revoked immediately upon written notice thereof.
   (d)   All tradesmen or person, businesses or corporations conducting work as
set forth herein above the specified areas, shall register annually with the
City, Administrative Division of Planning and Zoning in a manner prescribed by
rules as same may be established from time to time by said Planning and Zoning
Division or the Clerk of said Planning and Zoning Division.
   (e)   The annual registration fee shall be in accord with the provisions for
schedules and fees as set forth in
Chapter 208 and/or as codified.
   (f)   No tradesman or contractor performing services or work as identified
herein before who shall have failed to register as required herein and who
shall have failed to pay the fee designated as required herein, shall perform
any services or engage in any such business as identified herein within the
City.
   (g)   As used in this section, the word or words "tradesmen", "home
remodelers", "contractors", or "skilled tradesmen" shall mean and designate any
person, firm, business entity or corporation, whether acting as general
contractor or subcontractor, who engages in the business of erecting,
constructing and/or repairing buildings, permanent fixtures to real estate and
other permanent improvements to real estate within this City. The word
"contractor" shall specifically include, but not be limited to: builders,
excavators, remodelers, asphalt and concrete pavers, carpenters, roofers,
drywallers, plasterers, painters, wallpaperers, landscapers, basement
waterproofers, fence installers, home remodelers, and persons or entities
performing installation or improvement upon windows, doors, siding, driveways,
patios, swimming pools and other similar or ancillary work or improvements to
real property thereto.
   (h)   The City Administrator and Planning and Zoning Official hold the right
to deny a registration if the applicant fails to provide all the information
requested and/or does not meet the standards set place on the application. The
applicant may appeal the Board of Zoning Appeals.
   (i)   Whoever shall fail to register or conduct business in violation of the
registration requirements herein or violate any provision of this chapter shall
be subject to a doubled original registration fee. Failure to renew shall
result in an original registration fee.
(Ord. 2011-8.  Passed 5-12-11.)

822.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   “Juke box” means any music vending machine, contrivance or device
which, upon the insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate, disc or key into any
slot, crevice or other opening, or by the payment of any price, operates or may
be operated for the emission of songs, music or similar amusement.
   (b)   “Mechanical amusement device” means any machine which, upon the
insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate or disc, may be operated by the public
generally for use as a game, entertainment or amusement, whether or not
registering a score. It includes such devices as marble machines, pinball
machines, skill ball, mechanical grab machines and all games, operations or
transactions similar thereto regardless of their names.
   (c)   “Person,” “firm,” “corporation” and “association” mean and include the
following: any person, firm, corporation or association which owns any machine
defined in subsections (a) and (b) hereof; the person, firm, corporation or
association in whose place of business any such machine is placed for use by
the public; and the person, firm, corporation or association having control
over such machine.
(Ord. 77-47. Passed 10-13-77. )
822.02  GAMBLING DEVICES PROHIBITED.
   Nothing in this chapter shall in any way be construed to authorize, license
or permit any gambling device or any mechanism that has been judicially
determined to be a gambling device or in any way contrary to law or that may be
contrary to any future law of the State.
(Ord. 77-47. Passed 10-13-77. )

822.10  SEIZURE AND DESTRUCTION OF MACHINES.
   If the Chief of Police has reason to believe that any mechanical amusement
device is used as a gambling device, such machine may be seized by the police
and impounded and if, upon trial of the exhibitor for allowing it to be used as
a gambling device, such exhibitor is found guilty, such machine shall be
destroyed by the police.
(Ord. 77-47. Passed 10-13-77.)
822.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter, in addition to the
revocation of his license, shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars
($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 77-47. Passed 10-13-77.)
CHAPTER 826

826.01  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall conduct, stage or give a circus, menagerie, carnival,
sideshow, musical or minstrel entertainment or exhibition of monsters or freaks
of nature, for which money or reward is demanded or received, without first
obtaining a license and paying the fee provided for herein.
   The applicant for a license to conduct, stage or give such exhibition shall
give notice of at least one month in writing to the Mayor, stating the dates of
the performances, the location at which they are to be presented and the
sponsoring organization, if any. The Mayor, after receiving the approval of
Council, shall give his consent to the issuance of such license. Council shall
consider whether or not the location is suitable for the purpose; whether the
location will properly accommodate the patrons; whether the nature of the
performance or exhibition is morally proper; whether the use of such location
will throw an undue burden upon the Police or Fire Departments; and other
factors as might be brought to the attention of Council by the Mayor.
(Ord. 72-39. Passed 8-24-72.)
826.02  FEE.
   A fee as set forth in
Chapter 208 of the Administration Code - the General Fee Schedule - is required
for every circus, carnival, sideshow, musical or minstrel entertainment, which
fee shall be payable in cash to the Clerk-Treasurer.
(Ord. 72-39. Passed 8-24-72; Ord. 94-59. Passed 11-22-94.)
826.03  DEPOSIT REQUIRED.
   In addition to the fee required in Section
826.02 at the time of each application for a license for the use of Municipal
grounds or any street or alley within the Village, the applicant shall deposit
with the Clerk-Treasurer a cash deposit of one hundred dollars ($100.00)
conditioned upon the restoration and cleaning up of the grounds in a manner
satisfactory to the Mayor as concurred in by Council.  In the event such
grounds are restored and cleaned up properly following the exhibition, the
deposit shall be returned; otherwise the same shall be forfeited to the
Village.
(Ord. 72-39.  Passed 8-24-72.)
826.04  BOND REQUIRED.
   In addition to the fee and deposit required in Sections
826.02 and
826.03, before a license is issued, the applicant shall furnish a certified
copy and bond of a reputable insurance or bonding company licensed to do
business in the State, which bond shall indemnify the City for any and all
property damage or personal injury resulting from the conduct of such circus,
menagerie, carnival, sideshow, musical or minstrel entertainment in the amount
of not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000) for property damage and one
million dollars ($1,000,000) for personal injuries.
(Ord. 98-5.  Passed 3-12-98.)
826.05  WAIVER OF FEE.
   (a)   Any license fee required for any parade, circus, amusement or
entertainment, which activity is sponsored by a duly recognized departmental
unit of the Village, such as the Police Department, the Volunteer Fire
Department, the Recreation Board and the like, shall be waived.
   (b)   Requests for such waivers by any such departmental agency shall be in
writing and shall be submitted to the Clerk-Treasurer.  The Clerk-Treasurer
shall not issue a license, however, until Council has authorized the same.
(Ord. 74-35.  Passed 4-25-74.)
826.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not
more than one hundred dollars ($100.00).  A separate offense shall be deemed
committed each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.

CHAPTER 838
Hazardous Waste Landfills
838.01   Purposes.
838.02   Definitions.
838.03   Imposition of permit fee.
838.04   Northwood Hazardous Waste Landfill Environmental Protection Fund.
838.05   Periodic review of permit fee.
838.06   Records and reports.
838.07   Delinquency; surcharges and interest.
838.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Filthy accumulations - see GEN. OFF.
660.04
   Littering and dumping - see GEN. OFF.
660.14,
670.14,
Ch. 674
   Use of refuse containers - see GEN. OFF.
660.15
   Evergreen Landfill - see S. U. & P. S.
Ch. 1060
   Infectious waste disposal treatment facilities - see B . R . & T .
Ch. 840
838.01  PURPOSES.
   This chapter is enacted to protect the health, safety and welfare of the
residents of the City by generating funds not for general revenue purposes but
for the sole purpose of producing sufficient funds to monitor ground water and
surface water contamination; to provide funds to monitor air pollution
standards; to provide funds for road maintenance for hazardous waste
transportation to such sites; to provide funds for the extraordinary expenses
of police and fire protection to monitor the disposal of hazardous wastes; to
provide funds necessary for insurance premiums for liability insurance for the
City for potential future claims against the City resulting from the operation
of hazardous waste landfills; to provide funds for engineering, legal and other
professional services necessary to monitor the operation and results of the
hazardous waste landfills to ensure that all State and Federal regulations are
being complied with; and to provide funds for other expenses directly related
to monitoring the operation of hazardous waste landfill sites.
   A further purpose of this chapter is to meet the variety and complexity of
problems relating to water, air and land pollution in the City affected by any
hazardous waste landfill facility and to achieve a reasonable degree of purity
of water, air and land resources within the City consistent with the maximum
enjoyment and use thereof in furtherance of the health, safety and welfare of
the residents, as the same might be affected by local conditions because of the
contiguous land located in the City adjacent to a hazardous waste landfill
facility and other areas that are within the surrounding proximity of such
hazardous waste landfill facility that might be affected by the operation of
the hazardous waste landfill facility.
(Ord. 83-4. Passed 2-10-83. )
838.02  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "City" means the City of Northwood, Ohio.
   (b)   "Disposal" means the discharge, deposit, injection, dumping, spilling,
leaking or placing of any hazardous waste into or on any land or water so that
such hazardous waste or any constituent thereof may enter the environment or be
emitted into the air or discharged into any waters, including ground waters.
   (c)   "Facility" means any site, location, tract of land, installation or
building used for incineration, composting, sanitary landfilling or other
method for the storage, treatment or disposal of hazardous wastes.
   (d)   "Hazardous waste" has the same definitions given in the Ohio Revised
Code and, in addition, means any waste or combination of wastes in sold,
liquid, semisolid or contained gaseous form which, in the determination of the
Ohio Director of Environmental Protection, because of its quantity,
concentration or physical, chemical or infectious characteristics, may: (1)
Cause or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality or an increase in
serious irreversible or incapacitating reversible illness; or (2) Pose a
substantial present or potential hazard to human health or safety or to the
environment when improperly stored, treated, transported or disposed of, or
otherwise managed. Hazardous waste includes any substance identified by
regulation as hazardous waste under the "Resource Conservation and Recovery Act
of 1976," 90 Stat. 2806 to 2812, 42 U. S. C. 6921 to 6931.
   (e)   "Manifest" means the form used for identifying the quantity,
composition, origin, routing and destination of hazardous waste during its
transportation from the point of generation to the point of disposal, treatment
or storage.
   (f)   "Person" includes the State, any political subdivision and any other
state or local body, in addition to any legal entity defined as a person under
Ohio R. C. 1.59.
(Ord. 83-1. Passed 2-10-83.)
838.03  IMPOSITION OF PERMIT FEE.
   There is hereby imposed a permit fee on all hazardous waste disposed within
the City in accordance with any State permit. The fee shall be as set forth in
Chapter 208 of the Administration Code - the General Fee Schedule. The fee
shall be paid monthly to the Finance and Revenue Director of the City, based
upon the monthly totals of hazardous waste disposed of at the facility located
within the City limits according to the manifests filed by the operator of the
hazardous waste landfill with the regulatory agencies and according to such
other methods of determining tonnage as may be agreed upon by the City and the
facility operator.
   The permit fee shall be paid by the twenty-fifth day of each month following
the calendar month for which the report is filed.
   If any proper Court of record ever challenges the amount of the permit fee
imposed by this section, such fee shall not be reduced below the amount set
forth in
Chapter 208 of the Administration Code - the General Fee Schedule - by any
Court order, in compliance with the decision of the Supreme Court in the State
involving the Fondessy Enterprise Landfill, which Court found such amount for
hazardous waste deposit a reasonable fee.
(Ord. 86-77. Passed 12-30-86; Ord. 94-59. Passed 11-22-94.)
838.04  NORTHWOOD HAZARDOUS WASTE LANDFILL ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION FUND.
   There is hereby created a fund to be known as the Northwood Hazardous Waste
Landfill Environmental Protection Fund, which shall be the depository of all of
the permit fee proceeds generated by this chapter. Such Fund shall not be used
for any General Fund purpose of the City but shall be used solely to protect
the public health, safety and welfare of City residents, for expenses directly
related to the operation of the hazardous waste landfill facility, including,
but not limited to, the following items: to provide sufficient funds for the
City to pay the specialized and local costs of providing adequate fire and
police protection in connection with the placement of hazardous wastes in such
landfill; to provide funds for proper monitoring of litter control with respect
to the trucks utilizing the roadways to the hazardous waste landfill; to
provide funds for road maintenance for the weight of the trucks utilizing safe
roads to the hazardous waste landfill site; to provide funds for necessary
insurance premiums for liability insurance for the City for potential future
claims against the City resulting from the operation of the hazardous waste
landfill; to provide funds for engineering, legal and other professional
services necessary to monitor the operation and results of the operation of the
hazardous waste landfill site to ensure that all State and Federal regulations
are being fully complied with; to provide funds for scientific analysis of
surface water and/or ground water contamination during the operation of the
hazardous waste landfill; to provide funds for monitoring air pollution
resulting from the operation of the hazardous waste landfill site; and to
provide funds for other expenses directly related to the operation of the
hazardous waste landfill. If State law is amended and a fee or tax is levied on
hazardous waste or solid waste facilities or local governments are authorized
to levy such a fee or tax, and the proceeds of such fee or tax should go to the
City for purposes similar to the purposes enumerated in this section, the
permit fee established by this chapter shall be credited toward the payment of
such fee or tax.
(Ord. 83-4. Passed 2-10-83.)
838.05  PERIODIC REVIEW OF PERMIT FEE.
   Council, on or before April 15, 1985, and on or before April 15 of each odd
year thereafter, shall make a review of all expenditures made from the
Northwood Hazardous Waste Landfill Environmental Protection Fund during the
preceding two years to determine if the amount of the permit fee for hazardous
wastes should be increased, decreased or remain the same, so that sufficient
funds are generated to provide for the protection of the local environment in
order to protect the public health, safety and welfare of the residents of the
City. Such funds shall not exceed the amount necessary to carry out the
specific restricted purposes set forth in Section
838.04, but shall be sufficient to cover all costs incurred in the
administration of this chapter according to the purposes set forth in Section
838.01.
(Ord. 83-4. Passed 2-10-83.)
838.06  RECORDS AND REPORTS.
   Each operator of a hazardous waste landfill facility located within the City
shall keep complete and accurate records and manifests of the amount, type and
volume of hazardous waste disposed of within the facility each day.  Forms for
such records shall be provided by the Finance and Revenue Director and such a
form shall be filed with the Director on or before the twenty-fifth day of each
month for the activity of the previous month.  The form shall accompany the
monthly remittance of permit fees. 
(Ord. 83-4.  Passed 2-10-83.)
838.07  DELINQUENCY; SURCHARGES AND INTEREST.
   (a)   Original Delinquency. Any operator who fails to remit any permit fee
imposed by this chapter within the time required shall pay a surcharge equal to
ten percent of the amount of the permit fee, in addition to the permit fee.
   (b)   Continued Delinquency. Any operator who fails to remit any delinquent
remittance on or before thirty days following the date on which the remittance
first became delinquent shall pay a second delinquency surcharge equal to ten
percent of the amount of the permit fee and the previous penalty in addition to
the permit fee and the ten percent penalty first imposed. An additional penalty
equal to ten percent of the total permit fee and penalty of the previous
thirty-day period shall be added for each successive thirty-day period that the
operator remains delinquent.
   (c)   Fraud. If the nonpayment of any remittance under this chapter is due
to fraud, a surcharge equal to twenty-five percent of the amount of the fees
shall be added thereto in addition to the surcharges set forth in subsections
(a) and (b) hereof.
   (d)   Interest. In addition to the surcharges previously imposed, any
operator who fails to remit any fees imposed by this chapter shall pay interest
at the rate of one-half of one percent per month, or fraction thereof, on the
amount of the fees, exclusive of penalties, from the date on which the
remittance first became delinquent until paid.
(Ord. 83-4. Passed 2-10-83. )
838.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or
imprisoned not more than six months, or both, for each offense.
(Ord. 83-4. Passed 2-10-83. )
CHAPTER 840
Infectious Waste Treatment Facilities
840.01   Off-site infectious waste treatment facility and treatment facility
defined.
840.02   Fees for funding Municipal or Township programs and service.
840.03   Payment; return and remittance; delinquency.
840.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Spreading contagion - see GEN. OFF.

   Hazardous waste landfills - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 838
   Evergreen landfill - see S.U. & P.S.

840.01  OFF-SITE INFECTIOUS WASTE TREATMENT FACILITY AND TREATMENT FACILITY
DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter, “off-site infectious waste treatment facility” and
“treatment facility” mean an infectious waste treatment facility for which a
license is required under Ohio R.C. 3734.05(B).  “Off-site infectious waste
treatment facility” and “treatment facility” also mean a solid waste
incineration facility for which the license issued under Ohio R.C. 3734.05(A)
(1) includes the notation authorizing the treatment of infectious wastes made
pursuant to Ohio R.C. 3734.05(B)(3).
(Ord. 94-17.  Passed 3-10-94.)
840.02  FEES FOR FUNDING MUNICIPAL OR TOWNSHIP PROGRAMS AND SERVICE.
   (a)   Pursuant to Ohio R.C. 3734.024, any off-site infectious waste
treatment facility and treatment facility shall pay a fee as set forth in
Chapter 208 of the Administration Code - the General Fee Schedule - on the
treatment of infectious waste at that treatment facility.  This fee is an
addition to all other applicable fees and taxes and shall be added to any other
fee or amounts specified in the contract as charged by the owner or operator of
an off-site infectious waste treatment facility.
   (b)   Such fee shall commence on the sixtieth day after the adoption of this
chapter. 
(Ord. 94-17.  Passed 3-10-94.)
840.03  PAYMENT; RETURN AND REMITTANCE; DELINQUENCY.
   (a)   The owner or operator of an off-site infectious waste treatment
facility shall pay the fee set forth in Section
840.02 monthly to the Finance and Revenue Director.  The owner or operator
shall remit the fee.  The remittance shall be accompanied by a return
indicating the total amount of infectious waste received at the facility for
treatment during the month to which the return applies.  If a monthly return
and remittance of fees are not submitted to the City Clerk within sixty days
after the last day of the month to which the return and remittances apply, or
within sixty days after the date otherwise established in rules adopted under
Ohio R.C. 3734.026, the owner or operator shall pay a penalty of an additional
fifty percent of the remittance for each month that payment is late.
   (b)   The money received by the City Clerk shall be paid into the General
Fund of the City.
   (c)   No owner or operator of an off-site infectious waste treatment
facility shall violate or fail to comply with this section or a rule adopted
under authority of this section.
(Ord. 94-17.  Passed 3-10-94.)
840.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more
than ten thousand dollars ($10,000).  Each day during or on which a violation
occurs or continues shall constitute a separate offense.
   (b)   Upon a second or subsequent conviction for a violation of any
provision of this chapter, the offender shall be fined not less than twenty
thousand dollars ($20,000) nor more than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000) per
day of violation, or imprisoned not less than two years nor more than four
years, or both.
(Ord. 94-17.  Passed 3-10-94.)

860.01  SECONDHAND DEALER DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter, "secondhand dealer" means a person dealing in the
purchase or sale of secondhand articles of whatever nature, including antiques,
or dealing in the purchase or sale of any secondhand manufactured article,
composed wholly or in part of gold, silver, platinum or other precious metals,
for sale or otherwise using the same, or in the purchase or sale of old gold,
silver or platinum, for the purpose of melting or refining, or engaged in
melting precious metals for the purpose of selling, or in the sale of used or
secondhand articles of whatever nature taken as trade-ins on new merchandise
sold by such person, or in the purchase or sale of pawnbrokers' tickets, or
other evidence of pledged articles not being a pawnbroker, or in the redemption
or sale of furs, clothing or other pledged articles.
(Ord. 80-79. Passed 2-26-81.)
860.02  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (a)   No person shall be a secondhand dealer without first obtaining a
license therefor from the Finance and Revenue Director.  A separate license
shall be required for each separate location at which a business is conducted. 
No person for himself or herself, or as the agent of any dealer in secondhand
articles, shall solicit the purchase or sale of any of the articles or property
referred to in Section
860.01, within the City, without first obtaining a license therefor from the
Director.
   (b)   Application for such a license shall be made in writing to the
Director, upon such form as may be prescribed therefor by the Director, and
shall contain the name of the person applying for such license, the address or
addresses at which such business will be conducted, and such other information
as may be required by the Director.  If the applicant is a firm or corporation,
the application shall also contain the names of all persons interested
therein. 
(Ord. 80-79.  Passed 2-26-81.)
860.03  EXCEPTION.
   A person receiving any of the articles or items of property referred to in
Section
860.01 as trade-ins on new merchandise is not required to have a license for
the resale of such traded-in articles or items of property. 
(Ord. 80-79.  Passed 2-26-81.)
860.04  FEES.
   The fee for the license required by Section
860.02 shall be as set forth in
Chapter 208 of the Administration Code - the General Fee Schedule, which fee
shall be paid as an annual license fee for the issuance or renewal of such
license.
(Ord. 80-79.  Passed 2-26-81; Ord. 94-59.  Passed 11-22-94.)
860.05  RECORD OF PURCHASES.
   Every person licensed under Section
860.02 shall keep a book in which shall be written in ink in the English
language at the time of purchase of any secondhand article, a description
thereof, and the price paid the seller therefor, together with the age, address
and a personal description of the person from whom such purchase was made, and
also the date and hour of such purchase. The statement shall also be signed in
the book by the seller. Such book shall at all times be open to the inspection
of any member of the Police Department. Such book shall be substantially bound
and of a size not less than six inches in length and width. In addition to such
book, every person so licensed shall, at the time of such purchase, fill out on
a blank furnished by the Police Department such information as may be called
for by such blank form, and on the back of such blank form the seller shall
write in his or her own handwriting, his or her name, age and address. No entry
in such book or on such form shall be erased, obliterated, altered or defaced.
(Ord. 80-79. Passed 2-26-81. )
860.06  RETENTION OF ARTICLES.
   Every secondhand article purchased, received or obtained by any secondhand
dealer, except furniture received from a bona fide residence, store, warehouse
or factory, shall be held by such dealer for a period of fourteen days from the
date of the purchase or receipt thereof, unless the disposition of such article
is sooner authorized by the written permission of the Police Department.
(Ord. 80-79. Passed 2-26-81. )
860.07  RECORD OF SALES.
   At the time of the sale or disposition of a secondhand article, except
furniture received from a bona fide residence, store, warehouse or factory, the
secondhand dealer disposing thereof shall enter in his or her record book,
along with the entry made at the time of the acquisition of such secondhand
article, the name, address and description of the person to whom such
secondhand article is transferred, and shall obtain in ink in his or her record
book, the signature of the person acquiring such secondhand article.
(Ord. 80-79. Passed 2-26-81. )
860.08  RESTRICTIONS ON PURCHASES.
   (a)   No person licensed under Section
860.02 shall purchase any secondhand article from any person who is at the time
intoxicated or from an habitual drunkard or from any person who is known by him
or her to be a thief or an associate of thieves or from any receiver of stolen
property or from any person he or she has a reason to suspect to be such.
   (b)   No person shall receive, by sale, barter, exchange or otherwise, any
article mentioned in Section
860.01, from a minor, knowing or having reason to believe him or her to be
such, or from any person between the hours of 9:00 p. m. and 7:00 a. m.
(Ord. 80-79. Passed 2-26-81.)
860.09  REPORT REQUIRED WHEN RECEIVING CERTAIN USED ARTICLES.
   A person buying, receiving or taking in exchange any tires, used motor
vehicles, accessories or parts thereof, shall make a report to the Police
Department each morning of the tires, used motor vehicles, accessories or parts
thereof bought, received or taken in exchange during the preceding twenty-four
hours. Such persons shall fill out a form to be approved by the Police
Department, giving in the report a full description of the property bought,
received or taken in exchange.
(Ord. 80-79. Passed 2-26-81. )
860.10  DISPLAY OF LICENSE NUMBER ON VEHICLES.
   Any vehicle used by a secondhand dealer shall show on the right side
thereof, in a conspicuous place, the word "Licensed, " together with the number
of such license.
(Ord. 80-79. Passed 2-26-81.)
860.11  HOURS OF BUSINESS.
   No secondhand dealer shall keep open his or her place of business before the
hour of 6: 00 a. m. or after the hour of 8:00 p. m.
(Ord. 80-.79. Passed 2-26-81. )
860.12  RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Finance and Revenue Director is hereby authorized and directed to adopt
and promulgate such rules as he or she may deem necessary for the efficient
execution and performance of this chapter.
(Ord. 80-79.  Passed 2-26-81.)
860.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). A separate
offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation or
noncompliance occurs or continues.
(Ord. 80-79. Passed 2-26-81. )
CHAPTER 864

2006, and Ord. 2007-24, passed May 10, 2007.
CHAPTER 872
Vendors and Solicitors
872.01   Itinerant vendor defined.
872.02   Licenses required; fee.
872.03   Uninvited vendors prohibited.
872.04   Shopping centers.
872.05   Bond.
872.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Temporary stores - see Ohio R. C. 715.64
   Licenses - see B. R. & T.
Ch. 810
872.01  ITINERANT VENDOR DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter, "itinerant vendor" includes any person, natural or
artificial, who engages in or conducts a temporary or transient business of
selling goods, wares and merchandise within the Village with the intention of
continuing in such business in any one location for a period of not more than
four months and who, for the purpose of carrying on such business, hires,
leases or occupies in whole or in part any room, building or structure for the
exhibition and sale of such goods, wares and merchandise. The term does not
apply to hawkers or peddlers, to vendors engaged in the sale of food or food
products for human consumption, to commercial travelers or selling agents when
making sales in the usual course of business or to salesmen who sell by sample
for future delivery.
(Ord. 63-1. Passed 1-3-63.)
872.02  LICENSES REQUIRED; FEE.
   (a)   No itinerant vendor shall engage in such business without first
obtaining a license therefor and paying a fee therefor as set forth in
Chapter 208 of the Administration Code - the General Fee Schedule, for each day
that such business is carried on. Such license shall terminate automatically on
the last day for which such sum has been paid.
(Ord. 63-1. Passed 1-3-63; Ord. 94-59. Passed 11-22-94.)
   (b)   No transient vendor or limited vendor, as defined in Ohio R. C.5739,
shall engage in making retail sales without first obtaining a license therefor,
as required in Ohio R. C. Chapter 5739.
(Ord. 86-70.Passed 11-13-86.)
872.03  UNINVITED VENDORS PROHIBITED.
   No solicitor, peddler, hawker, itinerant merchant or transient vendor of
merchandise shall go in an upon any private residence in the Village not having
been requested or invited to do so by the owner or occupant of such private
residence for the purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares,
merchandise or services and/or disposing of and/or hawking the same.
(Ord. 64-24. Passed 11-5-64.)
872.04  SHOPPING CENTERS.
   The owner or manager of any shopping center larger than two acres located
within the City shall have the right to apply for a license under this chapter
for any and all institutions and organizations that might desire to utilize the
premises of such shopping center in order to conduct a business venture. The
owner or manager of such shopping center shall make application each year for a
license on behalf of such shopping center, the fee for which license shall be
as set forth in
Chapter 208 of the Administration Code - the General Pee Schedule. Such license
shall terminate automatically on the last day of the year for which it was
issued and such license shall be renewed on or before January 15 of each
succeeding year upon payment of the annual license fee as set forth in
Chapter 208 of the Administration Code - the General Fee Schedule, by such
owner or manager of the shopping center. The payment of such fee by the
shopping center owner or manager shall exempt all organizations from making
application and paying the license fee required under Section
872.02.
(Ord. 75-42. Passed 9-11-75; Ord. 79-81. Passed 11-29-79; Ord. 94-59. Passed
11-22-94.)
872.05  BOND.
   Each transient vendor, as defined in Ohio R. C.5739, shall file a bond and
other information with the County Sheriff, as required by Ohio R. C.311.
(Ord. 86-70. Passed 11-13-86.)
872.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter, for which no
penalty is otherwise provided, shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars
($100.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each
day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Adopting Ordinance)
   (b)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with Section
872.02(b) or 872.05 is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not
more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a first offense. For a subsequent
offense, such person is guilty of a misdemeanor of the second degree and shall
be fined not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) or imprisoned not
more than ninety days, or both.
(Ord. 86-70. Passed 11-13-86.)

Earned Income Tax Regulations Effective Through December 31, 2015
